blogs.title: Getting Started with React and TypeScript
blogs.description: Learn how to set up a new React project with TypeScript and understand the basics of type-safe component development.
blogs.content:
React and TypeScript together provide a powerful combination for building robust web applications. TypeScript adds static type checking to JavaScript, which helps catch errors early in the development process.

In this guide, we'll explore how to set up a new React project with TypeScript, understand the basics of typing components, props, and state, and learn best practices for type-safe development.

First, let's create a new project using Vite, which provides excellent TypeScript support out of the box. The development experience is fast and the build output is optimized for production.

blogs.title: Mastering TanStack Query for Server State
blogs.description: Discover how TanStack Query simplifies data fetching, caching, and synchronization in React applications.
blogs.content:
TanStack Query (formerly React Query) has revolutionized how we handle server state in React applications. Unlike client state, server state is inherently asynchronous and owned by another source.

TanStack Query provides powerful features like automatic caching, background refetching, stale-while-revalidate strategy, and optimistic updates. These features help create responsive and reliable user experiences.

In this article, we'll dive deep into query keys, mutations, cache invalidation, and advanced patterns that will level up your data fetching game.

blogs.title: Building Beautiful UIs with Tailwind CSS
blogs.description: A comprehensive guide to using Tailwind CSS for rapid UI development with utility-first approach.
blogs.content:
Tailwind CSS has changed the way developers approach styling. Instead of writing custom CSS, you compose designs using utility classes directly in your markup.

This utility-first approach offers several advantages: faster development, consistent designs, smaller production bundles, and easier maintenance. Once you understand the class naming conventions, you can build complex layouts without leaving your HTML.

We'll explore responsive design, dark mode implementation, custom configurations, and how to combine Tailwind with component libraries like shadcn/ui.

blogs.title: The Art of Clean Code Architecture
blogs.description: Explore principles and patterns for writing maintainable, scalable, and testable code in modern applications.
blogs.content:
Writing clean code is not just about making code workâ€”it's about making code that other developers (including your future self) can understand, maintain, and extend.

Clean architecture separates concerns, making each part of your application focused on a single responsibility. This separation makes testing easier, reduces coupling, and allows for independent development of features.

We'll discuss SOLID principles, component composition, proper state management, and folder structures that scale with your application.

blogs.title: Modern JavaScript Features You Should Know
blogs.description: Stay up to date with the latest JavaScript features that make your code more expressive and efficient.
blogs.content:
JavaScript continues to evolve with new features that make development more enjoyable and code more expressive. From ES6 onwards, we've seen significant improvements in syntax and capabilities.

Features like optional chaining, nullish coalescing, array methods, destructuring, and async/await have transformed how we write JavaScript. Understanding these features is essential for modern web development.

In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore practical examples and use cases for each feature, helping you write cleaner and more efficient code.

blogs.title: Understanding React Query Mutations
blogs.description: A practical guide to using mutations in TanStack Query for real-world apps.
blogs.content:
TanStack Query mutations are used to create, update, or delete data on the server.
Unlike queries, mutations represent actions that change state and therefore require
explicit control over side effects and cache updates.

One of the most powerful features of mutations is automatic cache invalidation.
After a successful mutation, related queries can be invalidated and refetched,
ensuring the UI stays consistent with the backend without manual state handling.

Mutations also provide built-in loading, error, and success states.
This makes it easy to show progress indicators, disable buttons during submission,
and handle failures gracefully without complex local state logic.

In real-world applications, mutations are commonly used for actions such as
creating blog posts, submitting forms, updating user profiles, and deleting records.
When combined with optimistic updates, they can deliver a fast and responsive user experience.

Understanding when and how to use mutations is essential for building reliable,
scalable React applications that communicate effectively with APIs.
